Package semplate.valuemap

Class ValueMap

java.lang.Object
semplate.valuemap.ValueMap
public class ValueMap
extends java.lang.Object
Maps values to field names.

  • Method Details

    • getValue

      public java.util.Optional<java.lang.Object> getValue​(java.lang.String fieldName)
      Returns an optional value mapped to the specified field name. The field name can be a simple field name, e.g.

      assertEquals("Plato", (String) valueMap.getValue("author");

      ...or can be a compound field name such as:

      assertEquals("Plato", (String) getValue("works.2.author");

      i.e. the author of the second element* in "works" list. Strictly speaking this is the element that is mapped to 2 in the "works" list.

      If the fieldname has not been specified for the value map or the value is of type ValueMap then an empty Optional is returned.

      Parameters:
      fieldName - The field name, either simple or compound.
      Returns:
      An Optional containing the value referenced by the field name or empty if the value could not be found

    • getValueMap

      public java.util.Optional<ValueMap> getValueMap​(java.lang.String fieldName)
      Returns an optional value map that is mapped to the specified field name.

      The field name can be a simple field name, e.g.

      assertEquals(referenceValueMap, (String) valueMap.getValue("reference");

      ...or can be a compound field name such as:

      assertEquals(referenceValueMap, (String) getValue("works.2.reference");

      i.e. the value map of the second element* in "works" list.

      If the fieldname has not been specified for the value map or the value is not of type ValueMap then an empty Optional is returned.

      Parameters:
      fieldName - The field name, either simple or compound.
      Returns:
      An Optional containing the value map.

    • getValueMaps

      public java.util.List<ValueMap> getValueMaps​(java.lang.String fieldName)
      Returns a list of ValueMaps that are subordinate to the specified fieldname.

      For instance: 

         ValueMap[] emperors = .....
   ValueMap vm = new ValueMap();
   vm.add("emperors", emperors[0]) 
   vm.add("emperors", emperors[1]) 
   vm.add("emperors", emperors[2])
   emperors.put("emperors", vm);
   emperors.getValueMaps("emperors");
      will return the value maps emperors[0], emperors[1] and emperors[2].

      As such the method can be viewed as returning a list of the value maps that have been added to a field.

      Graphically, with VM being a value map, v being a simple value and f a field name, an example value map structure can be represented as: 

             
                        +-----------+
                        |    VM0    |
                        +--+-+-+-+--+
        +----------------+ | | | | +---------------+
        |                  | | | |                 |
        |       +----------+ | | +---------+       |
      f1|     f2|            | |         f5|     f6|
        |       |        +---+ +--+        |       |
        |       |      f3|      f4|        |       |
      +---+  +--+--+  +-----+  +-----+  +--+--+  +---+
      | v1|  | VM1 |  | VM2 |  | VM3 |  | VM4 |  | v2|
      +---+  +-----+  ++-+-++  +-----+  +-----+  +---+
                       | | |
                +------+ | +-------+
              f7|      f8|       f9|
             +-----+  +-----+   +-----+
             | VM5 |  | VM6 |   | VM7 |
             +-----+  +-----+   +-----+

      Calling VM0.getValueMaps(f3) would return:

      {VM5, VM6, VM7}

      Calling VM0.getValueMaps(f2) would return:

      { } , i.e an empty list

      and calling VM0.getValueMaps(f1) would also return { }.

      Parameters:
      fieldName - The field name of the value maps containing the ordinal field names
      Returns:
      A list of value maps
      See Also:
      getValueMaps()

    • getValueMaps

      public java.util.List<ValueMap> getValueMaps()
      Returns a list of all value maps contained in the fields of this value map

      Graphically, with VM being a value map, v being a simple value and f a field name, an example value map structure can be represented as: 

               
                        +-----------+
                        |    VM0    |
                        +--+-+-+-+--+
        +----------------+ | | | | +---------------+
        |                  | | | |                 |
        |       +----------+ | | +---------+       |
      f1|     f2|            | |         f5|     f6|
        |       |        +---+ +--+        |       |
        |       |      f3|      f4|        |       |
      +---+  +--+--+  +-----+  +-----+  +--+--+  +---+
      | v1|  | VM1 |  | VM2 |  | VM3 |  | VM4 |  | v2|
      +---+  +-----+  ++-+-++  +-----+  +-----+  +---+
                       | | |
                +------+ | +-------+
              f7|      f8|       f9|
             +-----+  +-----+   +-----+
             | VM5 |  | VM6 |   | VM7 |
             +-----+  +-----+   +-----+
      Calling VM0.getValueMaps() would return:
      {VM1, VM2, VM3, VM4}
      Calling VM1.getValueMaps() would return:
      {VM5, VM6, VM7}
      and calling VM4.getValueMaps would return {}, i.e an empty list.
      Returns:
      A list of the value maps at the top level of this value map.
      See Also:
      getValueMaps(String)

    • put

      public ValueMap put​(java.lang.String fieldName, java.lang.Object dataObject)
      Sets a mapping between the specified field name and a value object. Field names can be simple (e.g. "name") or compound. Compound field names are formed using a dot notation, e.g. emperor.name A compound field name can contain any number of field names, e.g. emperor.5.consort.name Numbers can be used for field names to represent an ordinal position in a list. In the above this refers to the 6th (5 + 1) emperor in a a list. As far as this method is concerned, this is only a convention.
      Parameters:
      fieldName - The simple or compound field name
      dataObject - An object representing the value
      Returns:
      This value map. TODO Do we need the add function at all?

    • add

      public ValueMap add​(java.lang.String fieldName, java.lang.String ordinalFieldName, ValueMap map)
      Add a value map to a list of value maps associated with a field.

      For instance: 

         ValueMap vm = new ValueMap();
   vm.add("emperors", "0", emperorValueMap[0]);
   vm.add("emperors", "1", emperorValueMap[1]);
      will:
      1. create a new value map and map it to the field name "emperors"
      2. in the new value map will create a field "0" and map the value map emperorValueMap[0] to it.
      3. in the new value map will create a field "1" and map the value map emperorValueMap[1] to it.
      If the following line is then executed:

      vm.add("emperors", "0", emperorValueMap[3]);

      then the field emperors.0 will be replaced by emperorValueMap[3]

      Note: Although the parameter is called ordinalFieldName, the values do not need to be string representations of integers.

      Parameters:
      fieldName - The name of field to contain the mappings to the value maps
      ordinalFieldName - The name of the field that the added value map is mapped to
      map - The value map to be added
      Returns:
      This value map

    • merge

      public ValueMap merge​(ValueMap other)
      Merges a value map with this one.
      Parameters:
      other - The value map to be merged with this.
      Returns:

    • of

      public static ValueMap of​(java.util.List<java.lang.String> compoundFieldName, java.lang.String value)
      Returns a value map containing one value.

      If the compound field name list contains a single element (e.g "nomen"), and the value is "Augustus", then a value map is created with one field with one value, i.e. 

           (nomen="Augustus")
      If the compound field name list contains a more then one element then a set of nested value maps are created, with the last field name in the list being the field name of the specified value,# e.g. with a field name list of elements (emperors, 3, nomen) and the value of "Augustus", the following nested value ap structure is created: 
           (emperors=(3=(nomen="Augustus")))
      Parameters:
      compoundFieldName - An ordered list of fieldnames.
      value - The value of the specified field
      Returns:
      A ValueMap containing the specified element

    • of

      public static ValueMap of​(java.lang.String nameValuePair)
      Returns a value map containing one value constructed from the specified nameValuePair string.

      Examples:

      If the name value pair parameter contains a single element (e.g "nomen"), and the value is "Augustus", then the name value pair is specified using the following string: 

           "nomen=Augustus"
      This created a value map with one name value pair: 
           (nomen="Augustus")
      If the name value pair parameter contains a list of fieldnames seperated with dot characters, then a set of nested value maps are created, with the last field name being the field name of the specified value, e.g. the string: 
         "emperors.3.nomen=Augustus"
      results in a nested value map being created, i.e. 
            (emperors=(3=(nomen="Augustus")))
      Parameters:
      nameValuePair - A name value pair consisting of a dot separated list of bested field names, an equals sign and then the value in quotes.
      Returns:
      A ValueMap containing the specified element

    • from

      public static ValueMap from​(java.lang.Object dataObject) throws ConversionException
      Creates a value map from the specified data object.
      Parameters:
      dataObject - An object whose fields are annotated with @TemplateField
      Returns:
      The created value map
      Throws:
      ConversionException - if the data object cannot be converted to a value map.

    • from

      public static ValueMap from​(java.util.Iterator<?> iterator) throws ConversionException
      Creates a value map from the specified iterator.

      For instance: 

       List<String> list = Arrays.asList(new String[]{"Asimov", "Clark", "Pohl"});
 ValueMap valueMap = ValueMap.from(list.iterator());
      ... will create a value map with the following entries: 
       field name       value
 ==========      =======
     0           "Asimov"
     1           "Clark"
     2           "Pohl"
      Parameters:
      iterator - An interator over objects
      Returns:
      This value map
      Throws:
      ConversionException - If the iterator cannot be converted to a value map

    • toObject

      public java.lang.Object toObject​(java.lang.Class<?> objectClass) throws ConversionException
      Creates an object from the specified class using the data in this value map.
      Parameters:
      objectClass - The class of the object to be created
      Returns:
      An object populated with the values in this value map
      Throws:
      ConversionException - If the value map cannot be converted to an object
